Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The role of oxygen fugacity in calc-alkaline differentiation and the creation of continental crust at the Aleutian arc
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal seeks to examine the role of oxygen variations in the origin of the calc-alkaline magmas that erupt at subduction-related volcanoes (arc volcanoes). In particular, the PIs seek to determine how oxygen varies during differentiation and degassing, and see how it varies along strike of the Aleutian arc as a function of material derived from the subducted slab. The work will also include an experimental study of the relationship and interplay between H2O and fO2 during magma formation, a critical question with implications for the formation of continental crust. The PIs note that the Aleutian arc features local and regional variations in numerous geochemical features, but lacks the complexities introduced when magmas move through continental crust. The proposed work includes novel (micro XANES analysis of the ferrous/ferric ratio in glasses (a proxy for oxygen content), especially glass inclusions in mineral. Water, CO2 and major and trace elements (including Cl and S) will also be analyzed. The PIs also propose an experimental program in which fO2 is varied at constant water content. The experimental glasses will be analyzed using the same techniques as described for the natural glasses. Broader impacts include a new interactive exhibit at the Smithsonian that will include an on-line component. Material from the exhibits will be incorporated into undergraduate curricula. There will be undergraduate mentoring through REU and/or senior thesis, as well as mentoring of grad students and a post-doc.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Did you know that Earth is the only planet with continents? Continental rock contains little iron relative to the rocks that cover the other 70% of our planet (on the ocean bottom), and all the other rocky planets we know of. Why? How are continents formed? With this grant, we launched an expedition to the remote volcanoes of the Western Aleutians, Alaska - way out in the Bering Sea - to find out.

Western Aleutian volcanoes have been called a "continental nursery" because they erupt continent-like rocks even though they are in the middle of the ocean. When these volcanoes erupted, bits of magma trapped in minerals got "frozen in." We collected this type of material for the first time from some of these volcanoes. We are now analyzing this magma in laboratories at Smithsonian, University of Rhode Island, and Argonne National Laboratory, to see how much water and oxygen are dissolved in the magma. We hypothesize that these two factors unique to Earth, water and oxygen, drive the generation of continents.

It was dangerous to spend weeks on a tiny boat in the Bering Sea, flying to the rims of active volcanoes in a helicopter. But it was worth it! The expedition was a success. We returned hundreds of rock samples to the Smithsonian, where they will be studied for generations. To learn more about this expedition, you can discover the short Smithsonian documentary, "Expedition to Arctic Volcanoes," online; and you can look at the Twitter log of our journey @LizAleutians.

At the same time, we have constructed a new machine at the Smithsonian, capable of recreating the conditions under a volcano. We have placed rocks from the westernmost volcano in our study, Buldir Volcano, under conditions where it melts in a wet, oxidized environment. We see that these conditions reproduce many of the chemical signatures of continents.  Results from this study, and additional work performed at the University of California, Santa Barbara, on the radiogenic isotopes in these rocks, will appear in forthcoming publications.
